title: Foundations
description: Documentation for functions related to Foundations in Typst.

content.name: foundations
content.title: Foundations
content.details:
Foundational types and functions.

Here, you'll find documentation for basic data types like integers and strings as well as details about core computational functions.

items.name: assert
items.oneliner: Ensures that a condition is fulfilled.

items.name: auto
items.oneliner: A value that indicates a smart default.

items.name: calc
items.oneliner: Module for calculations and processing of numeric values.

items.name: datetime
items.oneliner: Represents a date, a time, or a combination of both.

items.name: dictionary
items.oneliner: A map from string keys to values.

items.name: duration
items.oneliner: Represents a positive or negative span of time.

items.name: eval
items.oneliner: Evaluates a string as Typst code.

items.oneliner: A mapping from argument values to a return value.

items.oneliner: A collection of variables and functions that are commonly related to a single theme.

items.oneliner: A value that indicates the absence of any other value.

content.name: arguments
content.title: Arguments
content.details:
Captured arguments to a function.

Argument Sinks

Like built-in functions, custom functions can also take a variable number of arguments. You can specify an argument sink which collects all excess arguments as ..sink. The resulting sink value is of the arguments type. It exposes methods to access the positional and named arguments.

#let format(title, ..authors) = {
  let by = authors
    .pos()
    .join(", ", last: " and ")

  [*#title* \ _Written by #by;_]
}

#format("ArtosFlow", "Jane", "Joe")

Spreading

Inversely to an argument sink, you can spread arguments, arrays and dictionaries into a function call with the ..spread operator:

#let array = (2, 3, 5)
#calc.min(..array)
#let dict = (fill: blue)
#text(..dict)[Hello]

details.content:
Construct spreadable arguments in place.

This function behaves like let args(..sink) = sink.

content.body:
#let args = arguments(stroke: red, inset: 1em, [Body])
#box(..args)

details.content: The arguments to construct.

scope.name: at
scope.title: At
scope.oneliner: Returns the positional argument at the specified index, or the named argument with the specified name.

details.content:
Returns the positional argument at the specified index, or the named argument with the specified name.

If the key is an integer, this is equivalent to first calling pos and then array.at. If it is a string, this is equivalent to first calling named and then dictionary.at.
The index or name of the argument to get.
A default value to return if the key is invalid.

scope.name: pos
scope.title: Positional
scope.oneliner: Returns the captured positional arguments as an array.

details.content: Returns the captured positional arguments as an array.

scope.name: named
scope.title: Named
scope.oneliner: Returns the captured named arguments as a dictionary.

details.content: Returns the captured named arguments as a dictionary.

content.name: array
content.title: Array
content.details:
A sequence of values.

You can construct an array by enclosing a comma-separated sequence of values in parentheses. The values do not have to be of the same type.

You can access and update array items with the .at() method. Indices are zero-based and negative indices wrap around to the end of the array. You can iterate over an array using a for loop. Arrays can be added together with the + operator, joined together and multiplied with integers.

Note: An array of length one needs a trailing comma, as in (1,). This is to disambiguate from a simple parenthesized expressions like (1 + 2) * 3. An empty array is written as ().

Example

#let values = (1, 7, 4, -3, 2)

#values.at(0) \
#(values.at(0) = 3)
#values.at(-1) \
#values.find(calc.even) \
#values.filter(calc.odd) \
#values.map(calc.abs) \
#values.rev() \
#(1, (2, 3)).flatten() \
#(("A", "B", "C")
    .join(", ", last: " and "))

constructor.name: array
constructor.title: Construct
constructor.oneliner: Converts a value to an array.

details.content:
Converts a value to an array.

Note that this function is only intended for conversion of a collection-like value to an array, not for creation of an array from individual items. Use the array syntax (1, 2, 3) (or (1,) for a single-element array) instead.

content.body:
#let hi = "Hello ðŸ˜ƒ"
#array(bytes(hi))

details.content: The value that should be converted to an array.

scope.name: len
scope.title: Length
scope.oneliner: The number of values in the array.

details.content: The number of values in the array.

scope.name: first
scope.title: First
scope.oneliner: Returns the first item in the array.

details.content: Returns the first item in the array. May be used on the left-hand side an assignment. Returns the default value if the array is empty or fails with an error is no default value was specified.
A default value to return if the array is empty.

scope.name: last
scope.title: Last
scope.oneliner: Returns the last item in the array.

details.content: Returns the last item in the array. May be used on the left-hand side of an assignment. Returns the default value if the array is empty or fails with an error is no default value was specified.
A default value to return if the array is empty.

scope.name: at
scope.title: At
scope.oneliner: Returns the item at the specified index in the array.

details.content: Returns the item at the specified index in the array. May be used on the left-hand side of an assignment. Returns the default value if the index is out of bounds or fails with an error if no default value was specified.
The index at which to retrieve the item. If negative, indexes from the back.
A default value to return if the index is out of bounds.

scope.name: push
scope.title: Push
scope.oneliner: Adds a value to the end of the array.

details.content: Adds a value to the end of the array.
The value to insert at the end of the array.

scope.name: pop
scope.title: Pop
scope.oneliner: Removes the last item from the array and returns it.

details.content: Removes the last item from the array and returns it. Fails with an error if the array is empty.

scope.name: insert
scope.title: Insert
scope.oneliner: Inserts a value into the array at the specified index, shifting all subsequent elements to the right.

details.content:
Inserts a value into the array at the specified index, shifting all subsequent elements to the right. Fails with an error if the index is out of bounds.

To replace an element of an array, use at.
The index at which to insert the item. If negative, indexes from the back.
The value to insert into the array.

scope.name: remove
scope.title: Remove
scope.oneliner: Removes the value at the specified index from the array and return it.

details.content: Removes the value at the specified index from the array and return it.
The index at which to remove the item. If negative, indexes from the back.
A default value to return if the index is out of bounds.

scope.name: slice
scope.title: Slice
scope.oneliner: Extracts a subslice of the array.

details.content: Extracts a subslice of the array. Fails with an error if the start or end index is out of bounds.
The start index (inclusive). If negative, indexes from the back.
The end index (exclusive). If omitted, the whole slice until the end of the array is extracted. If negative, indexes from the back.
The number of items to extract. This is equivalent to passing start + count as the end position. Mutually exclusive with end.

scope.name: contains
scope.title: Contains
scope.oneliner: Whether the array contains the specified value.

details.content:
Whether the array contains the specified value.

This method also has dedicated syntax: You can write 2 in (1, 2, 3) instead of (1, 2, 3).contains(2).
The value to search for.

scope.name: find
scope.title: Find
scope.oneliner: Searches for an item for which the given function returns `{true}` and returns the first match or `{none}` if there is no match.

details.content: Searches for an item for which the given function returns true and returns the first match or none if there is no match.
The function to apply to each item. Must return a boolean.

scope.name: position
scope.title: Position
scope.oneliner: Searches for an item for which the given function returns `{true}` and returns the index of the first match or `{none}` if there is no match.

details.content: Searches for an item for which the given function returns true and returns the index of the first match or none if there is no match.
The function to apply to each item. Must return a boolean.

scope.name: range
scope.title: Range
scope.oneliner: Create an array consisting of a sequence of numbers.

details.content:
Create an array consisting of a sequence of numbers.

If you pass just one positional parameter, it is interpreted as the end of the range. If you pass two, they describe the start and end of the range.

This function is available both in the array function's scope and globally.

content.body:
#range(5) \
#range(2, 5) \
#range(20, step: 4) \
#range(21, step: 4) \
#range(5, 2, step: -1)

details.content: The start of the range (inclusive).
The end of the range (exclusive).
The distance between the generated numbers.

scope.name: filter
scope.title: Filter
scope.oneliner: Produces a new array with only the items from the original one for which the given function returns true.

details.content: Produces a new array with only the items from the original one for which the given function returns true.
The function to apply to each item. Must return a boolean.

scope.name: map
scope.title: Map
scope.oneliner: Produces a new array in which all items from the original one were transformed with the given function.

details.content: Produces a new array in which all items from the original one were transformed with the given function.
The function to apply to each item.

scope.name: enumerate
scope.title: Enumerate
scope.oneliner: Returns a new array with the values alongside their indices.

details.content:
Returns a new array with the values alongside their indices.

The returned array consists of (index, value) pairs in the form of length-2 arrays. These can be destructured with a let binding or for loop.

content.body:
#for (i, value) in ("A", "B", "C").enumerate() {
  [#i: #value \ ]
}

#("A", "B", "C").enumerate(start: 1)

details.content: The index returned for the first pair of the returned list.

scope.name: zip
scope.title: Zip
scope.oneliner: Zips the array with other arrays.

details.content:
Zips the array with other arrays.

Returns an array of arrays, where the ith inner array contains all the ith elements from each original array.

If the arrays to be zipped have different lengths, they are zipped up to the last element of the shortest array and all remaining elements are ignored.

This function is variadic, meaning that you can zip multiple arrays together at once: (1, 2).zip(("A", "B"), (10, 20)) yields ((1, "A", 10), (2, "B", 20)).
Whether all arrays have to have the same length. For example, (1, 2).zip((1, 2, 3), exact: true) produces an error.
The arrays to zip with.

scope.name: fold
scope.title: Fold
scope.oneliner: Folds all items into a single value using an accumulator function.

details.content: Folds all items into a single value using an accumulator function.

content.body:
#let array = (1, 2, 3, 4)
#array.fold(0, (acc, x) => acc + x)

details.content: The initial value to start with.
The folding function. Must have two parameters: One for the accumulated value and one for an item.

scope.name: sum
scope.title: Sum
scope.oneliner: Sums all items (works for all types that can be added).

details.content: Sums all items (works for all types that can be added).
What to return if the array is empty. Must be set if the array can be empty.

scope.name: product
scope.title: Product
scope.oneliner: Calculates the product of all items (works for all types that can be multiplied).

details.content: Calculates the product of all items (works for all types that can be multiplied).
What to return if the array is empty. Must be set if the array can be empty.

scope.name: any
scope.title: Any
scope.oneliner: Whether the given function returns `{true}` for any item in the array.

details.content: Whether the given function returns true for any item in the array.
The function to apply to each item. Must return a boolean.

scope.name: all
scope.title: All
scope.oneliner: Whether the given function returns `{true}` for all items in the array.

details.content: Whether the given function returns true for all items in the array.
The function to apply to each item. Must return a boolean.

scope.name: flatten
scope.title: Flatten
scope.oneliner: Combine all nested arrays into a single flat one.

details.content: Combine all nested arrays into a single flat one.

scope.name: rev
scope.title: Reverse
scope.oneliner: Return a new array with the same items, but in reverse order.

details.content: Return a new array with the same items, but in reverse order.

scope.name: split
scope.title: Split
scope.oneliner: Split the array at occurrences of the specified value.

details.content: Split the array at occurrences of the specified value.

content.body: #(1, 1, 2, 3, 2, 4, 5).split(2)

details.content: The value to split at.

scope.name: join
scope.title: Join
scope.oneliner: Combine all items in the array into one.

details.content: Combine all items in the array into one.
A value to insert between each item of the array.
An alternative separator between the last two items.
What to return if the array is empty.

scope.name: intersperse
scope.title: Intersperse
scope.oneliner: Returns an array with a copy of the separator value placed between adjacent elements.

details.content: Returns an array with a copy of the separator value placed between adjacent elements.

content.body: #("A", "B", "C").intersperse("-")

details.content: The value that will be placed between each adjacent element.

scope.name: chunks
scope.title: Chunks
scope.oneliner: Splits an array into non-overlapping chunks, starting at the beginning, ending with a single remainder chunk.

details.content:
Splits an array into non-overlapping chunks, starting at the beginning, ending with a single remainder chunk.

All chunks but the last have chunk-size elements. If exact is set to true, the remainder is dropped if it contains less than chunk-size elements.

content.body:
#let array = (1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8)
#array.chunks(3) \
#array.chunks(3, exact: true)

details.content: How many elements each chunk may at most contain.
Whether to keep the remainder if its size is less than chunk-size.

scope.name: windows
scope.title: Windows
scope.oneliner: Returns sliding windows of `window-size` elements over an array.

details.content:
Returns sliding windows of window-size elements over an array.

If the array length is less than window-size, this will return an empty array.

content.body:
#let array = (1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8)
#array.windows(5)

details.content: How many elements each window will contain.

scope.name: sorted
scope.title: Sorted
scope.oneliner: Return a sorted version of this array, optionally by a given key function.

details.content:
Return a sorted version of this array, optionally by a given key function. The sorting algorithm used is stable.

Returns an error if a pair of values selected for comparison could not be compared, or if the key or comparison function (if given) yield an error.

To sort according to multiple criteria at once, e.g. in case of equality between some criteria, the key function can return an array. The results are in lexicographic order.

content.body:
#let array = (
  (a: 2, b: 4),
  (a: 1, b: 5),
  (a: 2, b: 3),
)
#array.sorted(key: it => (it.a, it.b))

details.content: If given, applies this function to each element in the array to determine the keys to sort by.

If given, uses this function to compare every two elements in the array.

The function will receive two elements in the array for comparison, and should return a boolean indicating their order: true indicates that the elements are in order, while false indicates that they should be swapped. To keep the sort stable, if the two elements are equal, the function should return true.

If this function does not order the elements properly (e.g., by returning false for both (x, y) and (y, x), or for (x, x)), the resulting array will be in unspecified order.

When used together with key, by will be passed the keys instead of the elements.

content.body:
#(
  "sorted",
  "by",
  "decreasing",
  "length",
).sorted(
  key: s => s.len(),
  by: (l, r) => l >= r,
)

scope.name: dedup
scope.title: Deduplicate
scope.oneliner: Deduplicates all items in the array.

details.content:
Deduplicates all items in the array.

Returns a new array with all duplicate items removed. Only the first element of each duplicate is kept.

content.body: #(3, 3, 1, 2, 3).dedup()

details.content: If given, applies this function to each element in the array to determine the keys to deduplicate by.

content.body: #("apple", "banana", " apple ").dedup(key: s => s.trim())

scope.name: to-dict
scope.title: To Dict
scope.oneliner: Converts an array of pairs into a dictionary.

details.content:
Converts an array of pairs into a dictionary. The first value of each pair is the key, the second the value.

If the same key occurs multiple times, the last value is selected.

content.body:
#(
  ("apples", 2),
  ("peaches", 3),
  ("apples", 5),
).to-dict()

scope.name: reduce
scope.title: Reduce
scope.oneliner: Reduces the elements to a single one, by repeatedly applying a reducing operation.

details.content:
Reduces the elements to a single one, by repeatedly applying a reducing operation.

If the array is empty, returns none, otherwise, returns the result of the reduction.

The reducing function is a closure with two arguments: an "accumulator", and an element.

For arrays with at least one element, this is the same as array.fold with the first element of the array as the initial accumulator value, folding every subsequent element into it.

content.body:
#let array = (2, 1, 4, 3)
#array.reduce((acc, x) => calc.max(acc, x))

details.content: The reducing function. Must have two parameters: One for the accumulated value and one for an item.

content.name: assert
content.title: Assert
content.oneliner: Ensures that a condition is fulfilled.

details.content:
Ensures that a condition is fulfilled.

Fails with an error if the condition is not fulfilled. Does not produce any output in the document.

If you wish to test equality between two values, see assert.eq and assert.ne.

Example

#assert(1 < 2, message: "math broke")
The condition that must be true for the assertion to pass.
The error message when the assertion fails.

scope.name: eq
scope.title: Assert Equal
scope.oneliner: Ensures that two values are equal.

details.content:
Ensures that two values are equal.

Fails with an error if the first value is not equal to the second. Does not produce any output in the document.

content.body: #assert.eq(10, 10)

details.content: The first value to compare.
The second value to compare.
An optional message to display on error instead of the representations of the compared values.

scope.name: ne
scope.title: Assert Not Equal
scope.oneliner: Ensures that two values are not equal.

details.content:
Ensures that two values are not equal.

Fails with an error if the first value is equal to the second. Does not produce any output in the document.

content.body: #assert.ne(3, 4)

details.content: The first value to compare.
The second value to compare.
An optional message to display on error instead of the representations of the compared values.

content.name: auto
content.title: Auto
content.oneliner: A value that indicates a smart default.
content.details:
A value that indicates a smart default.

The auto type has exactly one value: auto.

Parameters that support the auto value have some smart default or contextual behaviour. A good example is the text direction parameter. Setting it to auto lets Typst automatically determine the direction from the text language.

content.name: bool
content.title: Boolean
content.details:
A type with two states.

The boolean type has two values: true and false. It denotes whether something is active or enabled.

Example

#false \
#true \
#(1 < 2)

content.name: bytes
content.title: Bytes
content.details:
A sequence of bytes.

This is conceptually similar to an array of integers between 0 and 255, but represented much more efficiently. You can iterate over it using a for loop.

You can convert

  • a string or an array of integers to bytes with the bytes constructor
  • bytes to a string with the str constructor, with UTF-8 encoding
  • bytes to an array of integers with the array constructor

When reading data from a file, you can decide whether to load it as a string or as raw bytes.

#bytes((123, 160, 22, 0)) \
#bytes("Hello ðŸ˜ƒ")

#let data = read(
  "rhino.png",
  encoding: none,
)

// Magic bytes.
#array(data.slice(0, 4)) \
#str(data.slice(1, 4))

details.content:
Converts a value to bytes.

  • Strings are encoded in UTF-8.
  • Arrays of integers between 0 and 255 are converted directly. The dedicated byte representation is much more efficient than the array representation and thus typically used for large byte buffers (e.g. image data).

content.body:
#bytes("Hello ðŸ˜ƒ") \
#bytes((123, 160, 22, 0))

details.content: The value that should be converted to bytes.

scope.name: len
scope.title: Length
scope.oneliner: The length in bytes.

details.content: The length in bytes.

scope.name: at
scope.title: At
scope.oneliner: Returns the byte at the specified index.

details.content: Returns the byte at the specified index. Returns the default value if the index is out of bounds or fails with an error if no default value was specified.
The index at which to retrieve the byte.
A default value to return if the index is out of bounds.

scope.name: slice
scope.title: Slice
scope.oneliner: Extracts a subslice of the bytes.

details.content: Extracts a subslice of the bytes. Fails with an error if the start or end index is out of bounds.
The start index (inclusive).
The end index (exclusive). If omitted, the whole slice until the end is extracted.
The number of items to extract. This is equivalent to passing start + count as the end position. Mutually exclusive with end.

content.name: calc
content.title: Calculation
content.details:
Module for calculations and processing of numeric values.

These definitions are part of the calc module and not imported by default. In addition to the functions listed below, the calc module also defines the constants pi, tau, e, and inf.

functions.name: abs
functions.title: Absolute
functions.oneliner: Calculates the absolute value of a numeric value.

details.content: Calculates the absolute value of a numeric value.

content.body:
#calc.abs(-5) \
#calc.abs(5pt - 2cm) \
#calc.abs(2fr) \
#calc.abs(decimal("-342.440"))

details.content: The value whose absolute value to calculate.

functions.name: pow
functions.title: Power
functions.oneliner: Raises a value to some exponent.

details.content: Raises a value to some exponent.

content.body:
#calc.pow(2, 3) \
#calc.pow(decimal("2.5"), 2)

details.content:
The base of the power.

If this is a decimal, the exponent can only be an integer.
The exponent of the power.

functions.name: exp
functions.title: Exponential
functions.oneliner: Raises a value to some exponent of e.

details.content: Raises a value to some exponent of e.

content.body: #calc.exp(1)

details.content: The exponent of the power.

functions.name: sqrt
functions.title: Square Root
functions.oneliner: Calculates the square root of a number.

details.content: Calculates the square root of a number.

content.body:
#calc.sqrt(16) \
#calc.sqrt(2.5)

details.content: The number whose square root to calculate. Must be non-negative.

functions.name: root
functions.title: Root
functions.oneliner: Calculates the real nth root of a number.

details.content:
Calculates the real nth root of a number.

If the number is negative, then n must be odd.

content.body:
#calc.root(16.0, 4) \
#calc.root(27.0, 3)

details.content: The expression to take the root of.
Which root of the radicand to take.

functions.name: sin
functions.title: Sine
functions.oneliner: Calculates the sine of an angle.

details.content:
Calculates the sine of an angle.

When called with an integer or a float, they will be interpreted as radians.

content.body:
#calc.sin(1.5) \
#calc.sin(90deg)

details.content: The angle whose sine to calculate.

functions.name: cos
functions.title: Cosine
functions.oneliner: Calculates the cosine of an angle.

details.content:
Calculates the cosine of an angle.

When called with an integer or a float, they will be interpreted as radians.

content.body:
#calc.cos(1.5) \
#calc.cos(90deg)

details.content: The angle whose cosine to calculate.

functions.name: tan
functions.title: Tangent
functions.oneliner: Calculates the tangent of an angle.

details.content:
Calculates the tangent of an angle.

When called with an integer or a float, they will be interpreted as radians.

content.body:
#calc.tan(1.5) \
#calc.tan(90deg)

details.content: The angle whose tangent to calculate.

functions.name: asin
functions.title: Arcsine
functions.oneliner: Calculates the arcsine of a number.

details.content: Calculates the arcsine of a number.

content.body:
#calc.asin(0) \
#calc.asin(1)

details.content: The number whose arcsine to calculate. Must be between -1 and 1.

functions.name: acos
functions.title: Arccosine
functions.oneliner: Calculates the arccosine of a number.

details.content: Calculates the arccosine of a number.

content.body:
#calc.acos(0) \
#calc.acos(1)

details.content: The number whose arccosine to calculate. Must be between -1 and 1.

functions.name: atan
functions.title: Arctangent
functions.oneliner: Calculates the arctangent of a number.

details.content: Calculates the arctangent of a number.

content.body:

functions.name: atan2
functions.title: Four-quadrant Arctangent
functions.oneliner: Calculates the four-quadrant arctangent of a coordinate.

details.content:
Calculates the four-quadrant arctangent of a coordinate.

The arguments are (x, y), not (y, x).

content.body:
#calc.atan2(1, 1) \
#calc.atan2(-2, -3)

The Y coordinate.

functions.name: sinh
functions.title: Hyperbolic Sine
functions.oneliner: Calculates the hyperbolic sine of a hyperbolic angle.

details.content: Calculates the hyperbolic sine of a hyperbolic angle.

content.body:
#calc.sinh(0) \

functions.name: cosh
functions.title: Hyperbolic Cosine
functions.oneliner: Calculates the hyperbolic cosine of a hyperbolic angle.

details.content: Calculates the hyperbolic cosine of a hyperbolic angle.

content.body:
#calc.cosh(0) \
#calc.cosh(1.5)

functions.name: tanh
functions.title: Hyperbolic Tangent
functions.oneliner: Calculates the hyperbolic tangent of a hyperbolic angle.

details.content: Calculates the hyperbolic tangent of a hyperbolic angle.

content.body:
#calc.tanh(0) \
#calc.tanh(1.5)

details.content: The hyperbolic angle whose hyperbolic tangent to calculate.

functions.name: log
functions.title: Logarithm
functions.oneliner: Calculates the logarithm of a number.

details.content:
Calculates the logarithm of a number.

If the base is not specified, the logarithm is calculated in base 10.

content.body: #calc.log(100)

details.content: The number whose logarithm to calculate. Must be strictly positive.
The base of the logarithm. May not be zero.

functions.name: ln
functions.title: Natural Logarithm
functions.oneliner: Calculates the natural logarithm of a number.

details.content: Calculates the natural logarithm of a number.

content.body: #calc.ln(calc.e)

details.content: The number whose logarithm to calculate. Must be strictly positive.

functions.name: fact
functions.title: Factorial
functions.oneliner: Calculates the factorial of a number.

details.content: Calculates the factorial of a number.

content.body: #calc.fact(5)

details.content: The number whose factorial to calculate. Must be non-negative.

functions.name: perm
functions.title: Permutation
functions.oneliner: Calculates a permutation.

details.content:
Calculates a permutation.

Returns the k-permutation of n, or the number of ways to choose k items from a set of n with regard to order.

content.body:
$ "perm"(n, k) &= n!/((n - k)!) \
  "perm"(5, 3) &= #calc.perm(5, 3) $

details.content: The base number. Must be non-negative.
The number of permutations. Must be non-negative.

functions.name: binom
functions.title: Binomial
functions.oneliner: Calculates a binomial coefficient.

details.content:
Calculates a binomial coefficient.

Returns the k-combination of n, or the number of ways to choose k items from a set of n without regard to order.

content.body: #calc.binom(10, 5)

details.content: The upper coefficient. Must be non-negative.
The lower coefficient. Must be non-negative.

functions.name: gcd
functions.title: Greatest Common Divisor
functions.oneliner: Calculates the greatest common divisor of two integers.

details.content:
Calculates the greatest common divisor of two integers.

This will error if the result of integer division would be larger than the maximum 64-bit signed integer.

content.body: #calc.gcd(7, 42)

details.content: The first integer.
The second integer.

functions.name: lcm
functions.title: Least Common Multiple
functions.oneliner: Calculates the least common multiple of two integers.

details.content: Calculates the least common multiple of two integers.

content.body: #calc.lcm(96, 13)

details.content: The first integer.
The second integer.

functions.name: floor
functions.title: Floor
functions.oneliner: Rounds a number down to the nearest integer.

details.content:
Rounds a number down to the nearest integer.

If the number is already an integer, it is returned unchanged.

Note that this function will always return an integer, and will error if the resulting float or decimal is larger than the maximum 64-bit signed integer or smaller than the minimum for that type.

content.body:
#calc.floor(500.1)
#assert(calc.floor(3) == 3)
#assert(calc.floor(3.14) == 3)
#assert(calc.floor(decimal("-3.14")) == -4)

details.content: The number to round down.

functions.name: ceil
functions.title: Ceil
functions.oneliner: Rounds a number up to the nearest integer.

details.content:
Rounds a number up to the nearest integer.

If the number is already an integer, it is returned unchanged.

Note that this function will always return an integer, and will error if the resulting float or decimal is larger than the maximum 64-bit signed integer or smaller than the minimum for that type.

content.body:
#calc.ceil(500.1)
#assert(calc.ceil(3) == 3)
#assert(calc.ceil(3.14) == 4)
#assert(calc.ceil(decimal("-3.14")) == -3)

details.content: The number to round up.

functions.name: trunc
functions.title: Truncate
functions.oneliner: Returns the integer part of a number.

details.content:
Returns the integer part of a number.

If the number is already an integer, it is returned unchanged.

Note that this function will always return an integer, and will error if the resulting float or decimal is larger than the maximum 64-bit signed integer or smaller than the minimum for that type.

content.body:
#calc.trunc(15.9)
#assert(calc.trunc(3) == 3)
#assert(calc.trunc(-3.7) == -3)
#assert(calc.trunc(decimal("8493.12949582390")) == 8493)

details.content: The number to truncate.

functions.name: fract
functions.title: Fractional
functions.oneliner: Returns the fractional part of a number.

details.content:
Returns the fractional part of a number.

If the number is an integer, returns 0.

content.body:
#calc.fract(-3.1)
#assert(calc.fract(3) == 0)
#assert(calc.fract(decimal("234.23949211")) == decimal("0.23949211"))

details.content: The number to truncate.

functions.name: round
functions.title: Round
functions.oneliner: Rounds a number to the nearest integer.

details.content:
Rounds a number to the nearest integer.

Half-integers are rounded away from zero.

Optionally, a number of decimal places can be specified. If negative, its absolute value will indicate the amount of significant integer digits to remove before the decimal point.

Note that this function will return the same type as the operand. That is, applying round to a float will return a float, and to a decimal, another decimal. You may explicitly convert the output of this function to an integer with int, but note that such a conversion will error if the float or decimal is larger than the maximum 64-bit signed integer or smaller than the minimum integer.

In addition, this function can error if there is an attempt to round beyond the maximum or minimum integer or decimal. If the number is a float, such an attempt will cause float.inf or -float.inf to be returned for maximum and minimum respectively.

content.body:
#calc.round(3.1415, digits: 2)
#assert(calc.round(3) == 3)
#assert(calc.round(3.14) == 3)
#assert(calc.round(3.5) == 4.0)
#assert(calc.round(3333.45, digits: -2) == 3300.0)
#assert(calc.round(-48953.45, digits: -3) == -49000.0)
#assert(calc.round(3333, digits: -2) == 3300)
#assert(calc.round(-48953, digits: -3) == -49000)
#assert(calc.round(decimal("-6.5")) == decimal("-7"))
#assert(calc.round(decimal("7.123456789"), digits: 6) == decimal("7.123457"))
#assert(calc.round(decimal("3333.45"), digits: -2) == decimal("3300"))
#assert(calc.round(decimal("-48953.45"), digits: -3) == decimal("-49000"))

details.content: The number to round.

If positive, the number of decimal places.

If negative, the number of significant integer digits that should be removed before the decimal point.

functions.name: clamp
functions.title: Clamp
functions.oneliner: Clamps a number between a minimum and maximum value.

details.content: Clamps a number between a minimum and maximum value.

content.body:
#calc.clamp(5, 0, 4)
#assert(calc.clamp(5, 0, 10) == 5)
#assert(calc.clamp(5, 6, 10) == 6)
#assert(calc.clamp(decimal("5.45"), 2, decimal("45.9")) == decimal("5.45"))
#assert(calc.clamp(decimal("5.45"), decimal("6.75"), 12) == decimal("6.75"))

details.content: The number to clamp.
The inclusive minimum value.
The inclusive maximum value.

functions.title: Minimum
functions.oneliner: Determines the minimum of a sequence of values.

details.content: Determines the minimum of a sequence of values.

content.body:
#calc.min(1, -3, -5, 20, 3, 6) \
#calc.min("typst", "is", "cool")

details.content: The sequence of values from which to extract the minimum. Must not be empty.

functions.name: max
functions.title: Maximum
functions.oneliner: Determines the maximum of a sequence of values.

details.content: Determines the maximum of a sequence of values.

content.body:
#calc.max(1, -3, -5, 20, 3, 6) \
#calc.max("typst", "is", "cool")

details.content: The sequence of values from which to extract the maximum. Must not be empty.

functions.name: even
functions.title: Even
functions.oneliner: Determines whether an integer is even.

details.content: Determines whether an integer is even.

content.body:
#calc.even(4) \
#calc.even(5) \
#range(10).filter(calc.even)

details.content: The number to check for evenness.

functions.name: odd
functions.title: Odd
functions.oneliner: Determines whether an integer is odd.

details.content: Determines whether an integer is odd.

content.body:
#calc.odd(4) \
#calc.odd(5) \
#range(10).filter(calc.odd)

details.content: The number to check for oddness.

functions.name: rem
functions.title: Remainder
functions.oneliner: Calculates the remainder of two numbers.

details.content:
Calculates the remainder of two numbers.

The value calc.rem(x, y) always has the same sign as x, and is smaller in magnitude than y.

This can error if given a decimal input and the dividend is too small in magnitude compared to the divisor.

content.body:
#calc.rem(7, 3) \
#calc.rem(7, -3) \
#calc.rem(-7, 3) \
#calc.rem(-7, -3) \
#calc.rem(1.75, 0.5)

details.content: The dividend of the remainder.
The divisor of the remainder.

functions.name: div-euclid
functions.title: Euclidean Division
functions.oneliner: Performs euclidean division of two numbers.

details.content:
Performs euclidean division of two numbers.

The result of this computation is that of a division rounded to the integer n such that the dividend is greater than or equal to n times the divisor.

This can error if the resulting number is larger than the maximum value or smaller than the minimum value for its type.

content.body:
#calc.div-euclid(7, 3) \
#calc.div-euclid(7, -3) \
#calc.div-euclid(-7, 3) \
#calc.div-euclid(-7, -3) \
#calc.div-euclid(1.75, 0.5) \
#calc.div-euclid(decimal("1.75"), decimal("0.5"))

details.content: The dividend of the division.
The divisor of the division.

functions.name: rem-euclid
functions.title: Euclidean Remainder
functions.oneliner: This calculates the least nonnegative remainder of a division.

details.content:
This calculates the least nonnegative remainder of a division.

Warning: Due to a floating point round-off error, the remainder may equal the absolute value of the divisor if the dividend is much smaller in magnitude than the divisor and the dividend is negative. This only applies for floating point inputs.

In addition, this can error if given a decimal input and the dividend is too small in magnitude compared to the divisor.

content.body:
#calc.rem-euclid(7, 3) \
#calc.rem-euclid(7, -3) \
#calc.rem-euclid(-7, 3) \
#calc.rem-euclid(-7, -3) \
#calc.rem-euclid(1.75, 0.5) \
#calc.rem-euclid(decimal("1.75"), decimal("0.5"))

details.content: The dividend of the remainder.
The divisor of the remainder.

functions.name: quo
functions.title: Quotient
functions.oneliner: Calculates the quotient (floored division) of two numbers.

details.content:
Calculates the quotient (floored division) of two numbers.

Note that this function will always return an integer, and will error if the resulting number is larger than the maximum 64-bit signed integer or smaller than the minimum for that type.

content.body:
$ "quo"(a, b) &= floor(a/b) \
  "quo"(14, 5) &= #calc.quo(14, 5) \
  "quo"(3.46, 0.5) &= #calc.quo(3.46, 0.5) $

details.content: The dividend of the quotient.
The divisor of the quotient.

functions.name: norm
functions.title: ð‘-Norm
functions.oneliner: Calculates the p-norm of a sequence of values.

details.content: Calculates the p-norm of a sequence of values.

content.body:
#calc.norm(1, 2, -3, 0.5) \
#calc.norm(p: 3, 1, 2)

details.content: The p value to calculate the p-norm of.
The sequence of values from which to calculate the p-norm. Returns 0.0 if empty.

content.name: content
content.title: Content
content.details:
A piece of document content.

This type is at the heart of Typst. All markup you write and most functions you call produce content values. You can create a content value by enclosing markup in square brackets. This is also how you pass content to functions.

Example

Type of *Hello!* is
#type([*Hello!*])

Content can be added with the + operator, joined together and multiplied with integers. Wherever content is expected, you can also pass a string or none.

Representation

Content consists of elements with fields. When constructing an element with its element function, you provide these fields as arguments and when you have a content value, you can access its fields with field access syntax.

Some fields are required: These must be provided when constructing an element and as a consequence, they are always available through field access on content of that type. Required fields are marked as such in the documentation.

Most fields are optional: Like required fields, they can be passed to the element function to configure them for a single element. However, these can also be configured with set rules to apply them to all elements within a scope. Optional fields are only available with field access syntax when they were explicitly passed to the element function, not when they result from a set rule.

Each element has a default appearance. However, you can also completely customize its appearance with a show rule. The show rule is passed the element. It can access the element's field and produce arbitrary content from it.

In the web app, you can hover over a content variable to see exactly which elements the content is composed of and what fields they have. Alternatively, you can inspect the output of the repr function.

scope.name: func
scope.title: Func
scope.oneliner: The content's element function.

details.content: The content's element function. This function can be used to create the element contained in this content. It can be used in set and show rules for the element. Can be compared with global functions to check whether you have a specific kind of element.

scope.name: has
scope.title: Has
scope.oneliner: Whether the content has the specified field.

details.content: Whether the content has the specified field.
The field to look for.

scope.name: at
scope.title: At
scope.oneliner: Access the specified field on the content.

details.content: Access the specified field on the content. Returns the default value if the field does not exist or fails with an error if no default value was specified.
The field to access.
A default value to return if the field does not exist.

scope.name: fields
scope.title: Fields
scope.oneliner: Returns the fields of this content.

details.content: Returns the fields of this content.

content.body:
#rect(
  width: 10cm,
  height: 10cm,
).fields()

scope.name: location
scope.title: Location
scope.oneliner: The location of the content.

details.content: The location of the content. This is only available on content returned by query or provided by a show rule, for other content it will be none. The resulting location can be used with counters, state and queries.

content.name: datetime
content.title: Datetime
content.oneliner: Represents a date, a time, or a combination of both.
content.details:
Represents a date, a time, or a combination of both.

Can be created by either specifying a custom datetime using this type's constructor function or getting the current date with datetime.today.

Example

#let date = datetime(
  year: 2020,
  month: 10,
  day: 4,
)

#date.display() \
#date.display(
  "y:[year repr:last_two]"
)

#let time = datetime(
  hour: 18,
  minute: 2,
  second: 23,
)

#time.display() \
#time.display(
  "h:[hour repr:12][period]"
)

Datetime and Duration

You can get a duration by subtracting two datetime:

#let first-of-march = datetime(day: 1, month: 3, year: 2024)
#let first-of-jan = datetime(day: 1, month: 1, year: 2024)
#let distance = first-of-march - first-of-jan
#distance.hours()

You can also add/subtract a datetime and a duration to retrieve a new, offset datetime:

#let date = datetime(day: 1, month: 3, year: 2024)
#let two-days = duration(days: 2)
#let two-days-earlier = date - two-days
#let two-days-later = date + two-days

#date.display() \
#two-days-earlier.display() \
#two-days-later.display()

Format

You can specify a customized formatting using the display method. The format of a datetime is specified by providing components with a specified number of modifiers. A component represents a certain part of the datetime that you want to display, and with the help of modifiers you can define how you want to display that component. In order to display a component, you wrap the name of the component in square brackets (e.g. [year] will display the year). In order to add modifiers, you add a space after the component name followed by the name of the modifier, a colon and the value of the modifier (e.g. [month repr:short] will display the short representation of the month).

The possible combination of components and their respective modifiers is as follows:

  • year: Displays the year of the datetime.
    • padding: Can be either zero, space or none. Specifies how the year is padded.
    • repr Can be either full in which case the full year is displayed or last_two in which case only the last two digits are displayed.
    • sign: Can be either automatic or mandatory. Specifies when the sign should be displayed.
  • month: Displays the month of the datetime.
    • padding: Can be either zero, space or none. Specifies how the month is padded.
    • repr: Can be either numerical, long or short. Specifies if the month should be displayed as a number or a word. Unfortunately, when choosing the word representation, it can currently only display the English version. In the future, it is planned to support localization.
  • day: Displays the day of the datetime.
    • padding: Can be either zero, space or none. Specifies how the day is padded.
  • week_number: Displays the week number of the datetime.
    • padding: Can be either zero, space or none. Specifies how the week number is padded.
    • repr: Can be either ISO, sunday or monday. In the case of ISO, week numbers are between 1 and 53, while the other ones are between 0 and 53.
  • weekday: Displays the weekday of the date.
    • repr Can be either long, short, sunday or monday. In the case of long and short, the corresponding English name will be displayed (same as for the month, other languages are currently not supported). In the case of sunday and monday, the numerical value will be displayed (assuming Sunday and Monday as the first day of the week, respectively).
    • one_indexed: Can be either true or false. Defines whether the numerical representation of the week starts with 0 or 1.
  • hour: Displays the hour of the date.
    • padding: Can be either zero, space or none. Specifies how the hour is padded.
    • repr: Can be either 24 or 12. Changes whether the hour is displayed in the 24-hour or 12-hour format.
  • period: The AM/PM part of the hour
    • case: Can be lower to display it in lower case and upper to display it in upper case.
  • minute: Displays the minute of the date.
    • padding: Can be either zero, space or none. Specifies how the minute is padded.
  • second: Displays the second of the date.
    • padding: Can be either zero, space or none. Specifies how the second is padded.

Keep in mind that not always all components can be used. For example, if you create a new datetime with datetime(year: 2023, month: 10, day: 13), it will be stored as a plain date internally, meaning that you cannot use components such as hour or minute, which would only work on datetimes that have a specified time.

details.content:
Creates a new datetime.

You can specify the datetime using a year, month, day, hour, minute, and second.

Note: Depending on which components of the datetime you specify, Typst will store it in one of the following three ways:

  • If you specify year, month and day, Typst will store just a date.
  • If you specify hour, minute and second, Typst will store just a time.
  • If you specify all of year, month, day, hour, minute and second, Typst will store a full datetime.

Depending on how it is stored, the display method will choose a different formatting by default.

content.body:
#datetime(
  year: 2012,
  month: 8,
  day: 3,
).display()

details.content: The year of the datetime.
The month of the datetime.
The day of the datetime.
The hour of the datetime.
The minute of the datetime.
The second of the datetime.

scope.name: display
scope.title: Display
scope.oneliner: Displays the datetime in a specified format.

details.content:
Displays the datetime in a specified format.

Depending on whether you have defined just a date, a time or both, the default format will be different. If you specified a date, it will be [year]-[month]-[day]. If you specified a time, it will be [hour]:[minute]:[second]. In the case of a datetime, it will be [year]-[month]-[day] [hour]:[minute]:[second].

See the format syntax for more information.
The format used to display the datetime.
